docs.lead_paragraph: After workers around the country were laid off last fall, Kaylene Opperman sensed an opportunity. As chief nursing recruiter for Washoe Medical System, Reno's largest hospital, she figured that some of those workers were married to nurses, who might be willing to move their families to Reno. So she placed newspaper want ads in Florida, Missouri, Ohio, Texas and Utah. With the shortage of nurses growing worse by the year, hospitals are stepping up efforts to fill vacancies by selling themselves through advertisements, job fairs, even highway billboards. They are also trying to lure nurses with flexible hours, ever-larger signing bonuses and other financial incentives.

headline.main: Shortage of Nurses Spurs Bidding War In Hospital Industry

docs.abstract: Hospitals nationwide are suffering from shortage of nurses and have stepped up efforts to fill vacancies, selling themselves through advertisements, job fairs and even highway billboards; have turned against one another in biggest recruiting frenzy in more than decade, using sign-on bonus as popular recuriting tool; currently have 126,000 nursing vacancies, or 12 percent of capacity, and industry experts predict number could triple over next decade as baby boomers age; problem's roots date back decade, when health system shifted to managed care, hospitals merged, and nurses were laid off to cut costs; another factor is nursing salaries, which have remained relatively flat for decade, with national average at $45,550 a year; shortage has forced many states, especially those with fast-growing populations, to spend more for nursing schools and recruitment; Congress, in addition, is completing legislation that would generate $136.7 million in new federal spending for scholarships, loan repayments and recruitment grants; maps; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Early this year Congress and the White House entertained dreams of passing all kinds of health care legislation. President Bush and Senator Edward Kennedy were supposedly working on a patients' ''bill of rights.'' There was even talk of enacting a prescription drug benefit for the elderly. But such talk has vanished. Instead a sober recognition has settled in Washington that little can be done to expand or improve health coverage while health care costs spiral out of control and the federal budget sinks deeper into deficit. Lawmakers seem to be betting that voters will not punish them for inaction. But they cannot put off the issue forever. A decade ago, when the cost of health care was also soaring, many experts were sure they had a solution -- managed care and competition. A revolution in health care delivery took place, and costs indeed seemed under control. But in the last couple of years they have gone back to rising at double-digit rates. Even the experts are shaken, because there is no magic solution this time around. Health maintenance organizations and insurance companies are not high on anyone's list of favorite enterprises. But in the current environment, lawmakers seem loath to add new requirements like a patient's right to sue, or parity between regular health care and mental health benefits, because of the cost.

The tests are CT scans of the body -- high-speed, highly sensitive X-rays that can find tiny tumors, weak spots on blood vessels that make them bulge out like balloons, and calcified areas that may be indicative of heart disease.

headline.main: Cheaper Body Scans Spread, Despite Doubts

docs.lead_paragraph: IF art in the broadest sense peers into the mysteries of life, then an art dedicated to the structure of life itself is of momentous relevance. That imposing premise informs ''Gene(sis): Contemporary Art Explores Human Genomics,'' an exhibition that opened in April at the University of Washington's Henry Art Gallery in Seattle. At once clever and awkward, the show's title evokes the biblical loftiness of Divine Origin and an altogether cooler scrutiny of the scientific, ethical and legal issues pulsing from the very nucleus of our genetic being.

docs.lead_paragraph: As a primary-care physician, I believe that the doctor's dilemma described in Friedman's article may be even more complicated than your writer suggests. And those of us who are patients and insurance beneficiaries are implicated also. Let's take another look at Jim Levine's day. Eight sore throats: these are almost always viral. The normal immune system can easily handle these viruses, and the patient will feel better in a week. Young, healthy, asymptomatic Americans do not need annual physicals; at most, they need a blood-pressure check (high blood pressure has no symptoms) and, in their 30's, a cholesterol test. Young people with no symptoms and no risk factors for heart disease need no more than one EKG, for baseline. Obesity is a major health problem in the country, but Weight Watchers and the public health system can address it more effectively and efficiently than I can. In other words, many of Levine's patients need not have visited the doctor at all that day. And with those patients off his schedule, there would have been more time for people who need his care. However, his patients had insurance; he needs to support a family; and it is safer to see healthy patients with trivial complaints, especially if time is short. Caroline Poplin, M.D. Bethesda, Md.

docs.lead_paragraph: THERE is a campaign being waged in New Jersey against the victims of medical malpractice. The malpractice insurance industry seeks legislation that will deprive malpractice victims of their day in court. The supporters of so-called tort-reform point to the fact that New Jersey's second-largest medical malpractice insurer, the Medical Inter-Insurance Exchange, known as MIIX, announced last week that it plans to cease operations in its present form. As a result, there is only one insurance company in New Jersey, The Princeton Insurance Company, willing to write malpractice coverage. Insurance rates are increasing, and doctors in New Jersey say they must abandon their practices because of the cost of malpractice insurance. However, there is no legitimate reason medical malpractice insurance is not available and affordable in New Jersey. The number of malpractice suits in the state declined from 2,200 in 1994 to 1,613 in 2001, a decrease of more than 25 percent. This decrease is the result of a law passed in 1995 requiring that a medical expert swear under oath at the beginning of every case that the claim has merit.

docs.lead_paragraph: On the subject of a concierge medical practice, I wonder about the interface between the primary-care physician and any specialists who may be required to care for the patient. Is the boutique doc the advocate for the patient, for all that money? If the boutique doc goes to specialty appointments with the patient, is this to ensure that the patient is properly educated, to ensure that appointments go smoothly, or is it to influence the specialist to provide a different level of care to that patient? The whole idea of boutique practice reeks. God help the primary-care doctor who tries to intimidate anyone in my office for care different from that given to the poorest or wealthiest patient on conventional insurance, or even to the uninsured. Jeffrey L. Kaufman, M.D. Springfield, Mass.

docs.lead_paragraph: Why criticize doctors who want to provide excellent care to a small group of patients rather than cursory care to an outrageously unmanageable ''panel size of 4,200 patient lives''? Why not put the blame instead on the managed-care bureaucracy that insists its roster doctors see 24 patients a day and then spend more time handling the overwhelming paperwork? If some physicians want to opt out of this unsatisfying situation, I say kudos to them for refusing to bow down to a dangerously demoralizing system. Let the H.M.O.'s answer for the plight of patients who can no longer afford quality care. Rina Kleege New York
